Award.AwardTitle: Implementation of a Pilot Program for Successfully Transitioning Veterans Entering STEM programs at Mississippi State University

Division.LongName: Div Of Engineering Education and Centers

Award.AbstractNarration: This engineering education research project seeks to establish a recruiting and retention program for veterans at Mississippi State University in partnership with the Mississippi College for Women. The research project, if successful, will create a portable, modular set of courses to transition veterans to college engineering programs and collect data on their effectiveness. A key element of this project is integrating research on learning preferences into the development of the transition modules. The broader significance and importance of this project will be to develop tested modules which other institutions and organizations can use to transition military veterans to college degree programs. The research effort partners with veterans organizations and professional associations to adopt best practices in recruiting under-represented students. The discoveries that may result from the modular courses to transition students will have broad applicability across organizations that deal with military veterans. This research project will enhance the number of students who complete engineering degrees and are ready to fill engineering jobs or start new high tech businesses.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Military veterans present a source of educated and motivated individuals who have the ability to fill critical positions in the science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM) field. However, the majority of these individuals has not been in a formal educational environment for several years and would benefit from a review of some basics skills before entering college. Technical communication skills is one area which has been noticed as needing improving by both college faculty and military veterans. Being successful in early college courses is essential to long-term retention in and graduation from college.

 

Military veterans are also in getting their college educations completed as soon as possible in order to move forward with their lives and maximize the educational benefits provided to them under the Montgomery GI Bill. Therefore they do not wish to take remedial or preparatory courses unless they are necessary. Through previous research we recognized that the issue for many veterans is not that they do not possess the needed technical communication skills but they have simply not used them in several years. A refresher rather than a remedial course is what they needed.

 

Through this project a series of short on-line modules or tutorials were developed for veterans. These modules assessed the current level of technical communication skills the veteran had and then allowed them to review and complete exercises in their weak areas. Ideally this work would be able to be completed before a veteran leaves active duty and make for an easier transition into a STEM field at college.

 

In discussing this project with faculty at other institutions, it was noted that although this research was focused on those leaving the military and pursuing a baccalaureate degree, and similar need also existed for those leaving the military to pursue a graduate education. The technical skills needed to succeed in graduate school are certainly different than those required for a baccalaureate degree. The skills currently possessed by a veteran entering graduate school are also different but a similar model could be developed and implemented. It was beyond the scope of this project to develop such a model but this project could serve as the foundation of such work.

 

Initial results of this project appear promising. One student who took a class from one of the researchers noted that it was much easier to write a required paper and that he had more confidence in his writing ability as a result of his participation in the project. The student did indeed earn a high grade on the assignment. Having such early “wins” in college will result in improved retention and graduation rates of veterans. Ultimately they will be able to fill the shortage the nation has in STEM fields.
